awd_titl_txt: Career: The Effects of Public Policy on Families with Children: New Evidence from Multiple Large-Scale Data Sets
awd_abstract_narration:
Millions of families face challenges of work-family balance, single parenthood, and poverty. Public policies could improve the lives of families dealing with these issues, but the intended impacts of these policies may not be achieved if families respond to policies in unpredictable ways. Moreover, policies with overlapping goals that are targeted at the same families could either work together to benefit these families or work against each other. Understanding how these policies comprehensively affect families---working independently or together---is essential for informing government spending decisions, and thereby advancing national health, prosperity, and welfare. This CAREER research program combines multiple large-scale data sets with experimental research methods to better understand the effects of public policies on family outcomes and promote the progress of economic science.  Specifically, the research project will study the effects of paid family leave, joint custody laws, and major U.S. social safety net programs on family outcomes. This proposal's education plan centers on training students---especially women, who are under-represented in the economics profession---to shape the next generation of researchers who will be involved in public policy.  The results of this research project will have profound influence on the conduct of public policy towards families, hence increase the well-being of Americans. 

This CAREER research project has four components. The first project uses population-level administrative data to estimate the impacts of California's paid family leave (PFL) benefits on leave duration, labor market outcomes, and repeat leave-taking among new parents with a regression kink research design. This project provides some of the first estimates of the effects of the PFL benefit amount, holding other policies constant. The second project will identify the causal effects of joint legal custody, which grants both parents the right to make key decisions about their children's welfare and is increasingly promoted by legislation in the developed world, on family outcomes. This project will use Danish administrative data on custody court cases linked to four other administrative data sets to track the economic, family formation, and mental and physical health outcomes of the parents and children in each case. To identify causality, the project will leverage random assignment of custody cases to judges, who differ in their propensity to grant joint legal custody. The third project will analyze the long-term effects of U.S. safety net programs with data on millions of current adults, focusing on two questions: (i) Do safety net programs ameliorate adverse long-term consequences of early childhood economic shocks? (ii) Do these programs complement or substitute each other in their long-term impacts on adult outcomes? The analysis will use difference-in-difference and event-study designs, exploiting variation from the county-by-county rollout of major programs, and variation in local labor demand. The fourth component is a mentoring workshop that connects female economics PhD students with mentors who are in the early stages of their careers both within and outside academia.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
NSF-CAREER 1752203 Project Outcomes Report

PI: Maya Rossin-Slater

“The Effects of Public Policy on Families with Children: New Evidence from Multiple Large-Scale Data Sets”

Millions of modern families face the challenges of work-family balance, single parenthood, and poverty. Public policies that target these issues could have transformative consequences, but credible estimates of policy impacts on a comprehensive set of outcomes are critical for evaluating their effectiveness and identifying areas that need reform. This CAREER project has studied these issues using multiple large-scale data sources with quasi-experimental research designs. Additionally, this project's educational plan involved mentoring women and non-binary PhD students in economics and related fields, who have been historically under-represented in the profession, and who will contribute to the next generation of public policy makers and knowledge generators. The project incorporated four components

The first component analyzed California’s paid family leave (PFL) policy, using administrative data on paid leave claims linked to quarterly earnings records from the state. The project found that a higher weekly benefit amount does not change leave duration or lead to adverse future labor market outcomes among new mothers; instead, it increases the likelihood that she returns to her pre-leave employer and makes a subsequent paid leave claim. The project also documented a substantial amount of inequality in the use of PFL and disability insurance (DI) benefits in California across workers at different firms, and that better-paying firms tend to have higher benefit take-up rates. The second component used administrative data from Sweden to study how fathers’ access to more workplace flexibility in the weeks following their child’s birth affects maternal postpartum health. It found that a reform that increased fathers’ ability to take time off work during the postpartum period reduced the incidence of maternal physical and mental health complications. The third component studied two major US social safety net programs: the Food Stamps program (now known as the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, or SNAP) and the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children (WIC). The project used novel, large-scale data on 43 million Americans from the 2000 Census and the 2001 to 2013 American Communities Survey linked to the Social Security Administration’s NUMIDENT file to study how access to Food Stamps for families affects children’s long-term outcomes. Using variation from the county-level roll-out of the Food Stamps program between 1961 and 1975, the project found that children with access to the program before age five experience better adult educational and economic outcomes, live longer, and are less likely to be incarcerated as adults. With regard to the WIC program, the project analyzed a 2012 reform of California’s program that reduced the number of small vendors participating in it. The analysis found that having access to a small  vendor in one’s residence ZIP code increases benefit take-up among first-time and foreign-born mothers,  suggesting that small vendors are distinctly effective at lowering take-up barriers among women with high program learning costs. This finding implies that cost containment reforms may have unintended consequences of inequitably reducing program access. The fourth component was an annual mentoring workshop that connected women and non-binary PhD students in economics and related fields with mentors who are in the early stages of their careers both within and outside of academia. This workshop was held annually five times over the award period, serving over 500 students from around the world. Other institutions and organizations have since organized similar workshops, following materials originally created by the PI of this award.

This project’s intellectual merit contribution was to investigate policy-relevant research questions using leading applied microeconomics methods designed to produce causal estimates. It used multiple large administrative and survey data sets, some of which had been never used for academic research before. It advanced knowledge on these issues through multiple high-impact publications in leading peer-reviewed journals, including Review of Economic Studies, American Economic Journal: Applied Economics, and Journal of Policy Analysis and Management.

The project’s broader impacts have been achieved through the dissemination of research findings that are informative to policymakers at both state and national levels. For example, research findings from this project were cited in the 2023 Economic Report of the President, the White House Blueprint for Addressing the Maternal Health Crisis, and leading media outlets like The New York Times. Additionally, the education portion (fourth component) has contributed to training individuals who have been historically underrepresented in the economics profession, and who are likely to have broad impacts in academia and public policy.  

 


Last Modified: 07/18/2024
Modified by: Maya Rossin-Slater

 The Effects of Public Policy on Families with Children: New Evidence from Multiple Large-Scale Data Sets


Millions of modern families face the challenges of work-family balance, single parenthood, and poverty. Public policies that target these issues could have transformative consequences, but credible estimates of policy impacts on a comprehensive set of outcomes are critical for evaluating their effectiveness and identifying areas that need reform. Additionally, this project's educational plan involved mentoring women and non-binary PhD students in economics and related fields, who have been historically under-represented in the profession, and who will contribute to the next generation of public policy makers and knowledge generators. The first component analyzed Californias paid family leave (PFL) policy, using administrative data on paid leave claims linked to quarterly earnings records from the state. It used multiple large administrative and survey data sets, some of which had been never used for academic research before. For example, research findings from this project were cited in the 2023 Economic Report of the President, the White House Blueprint for Addressing the Maternal Health Crisis, and leading media outlets like The New York Times.
